**Discharge Letter:**

Patient Name: John Doe  
Age: 45  
Date of Admission: March 15, 2024  
Date of Discharge: March 22, 2024  

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to inform you about the discharge of Mr. John Doe, a 45-year-old male who was admitted to our hospital on March 15, 2024, complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Upon admission, Mr. Doe was promptly evaluated by our medical team.

During his hospitalization, Mr. Doe underwent several diagnostic tests, including a chest X-ray, an electrocardiogram (ECG), and a blood panel. The results revealed evidence of myocardial infarction, necessitating urgent intervention.

On March 16, 2024, Mr. Doe underwent a coronary angiography, which confirmed significant blockage in his left anterior descending artery. Subsequently, on March 18, 2024, he underwent a successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

Following the procedure, Mr. Doe was closely monitored in the cardiac care unit (CCU). He responded well to treatment and showed signs of clinical improvement. Daily assessments of his vital signs and cardiac function were performed, and he remained hemodynamically stable throughout his hospital stay.

On March 22, 2024, after seven days of hospitalization, Mr. Doe's condition had significantly improved, and he was deemed medically stable for discharge. He was provided with detailed instructions regarding medication regimen, dietary modifications, and follow-up appointments with his cardiologist.

We anticipate a smooth recovery for Mr. Doe and encourage him to adhere to the prescribed treatment plan to optimize his cardiac health.

Sincerely,

[Physician's Signature]  
Dr. Emily Johnson  
Cardiologist
